RGBlimp-Q: Robotic Gliding Blimp
With Moving Mass Control
Based on a Bird-Inspired Continuum Arm

Hao Cheng   and   Feitian Zhang*
Peking University
h-cheng@stu.pku.edu.cn   feitian@pku.edu.cn  
* Corresponding author
Paper arXiv Video Hardward & Code

Abstract

Miniature robotic blimps, as lighter-than-air aerial systems, offer prolonged duration and safety interaction capabilities in the air, benefiting from buoyant lift. However, agile maneuver and robust flight against environmental disturbances are long-standing challenges, hindering a wider application scope of these robots.

Leveraging insights from the flight mechanics of birds and their ability to perch against natural wind, this paper introduces RGBlimp-Q, a robotic gliding blimp equipped with a bird-inspired continuum arm. The arm enables attitude adjustments through moving mass control for maneuverability and disturbance resilience, while also facilitating object capture using claws to counteract environmental disturbances, like flying animals. This paper presents the design, dynamic modeling, and prototyping of RGBlimp-Q, paving the way for extending the advantages of robotic blimps to complex environments. Experimental results from indoor and outdoor settings are presented to confirm the improved flight maneuverability and robustness against environmental disturbances afforded by the proposed design.

We have open-sourced the RGBlimp-Q hardware and code on GitHub.
